channel.title: CMD Promp in application?
channel.description: I have been wondering how this is done, If you do not know what i am talking about, i am referring to the black 'box' on the bottom of SIDE or Moparscape client.

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:17, topic:176880”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=237664.msg2024634#msg2024634 date=1201835206]

public class Test {
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		System.out.println("Test 1");
		javax.swing.JFrame frame = new javax.swing.JFrame("Test Frame");
		frame.setSize(300, 300);
		javax.swing.JTextArea area = new javax.swing.JTextArea();
		java.io.PrintStream stream = System.out;
		System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(area, stream));
		frame.add(new javax.swing.JScrollPane(area));
		frame.setVisible(true);
		System.out.println("Test 2");
		System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(null, stream));
		System.out.println("Test 3");
	}
}

private class TestPrintStream extends java.io.PrintStream {
	javax.swing.TextArea area;

	public TestPrintStream(javax.swing.TextArea area, java.io.PrintStream stream) {
		super(stream);
		this.area = area;
	}

	public void println(String str) {
		if (area != null)
			area.setText(area.getText() + str + "\n");
		else
			super.println(str);
	}
}

I made this just now so I do not know if it would compile. However, if it would, it would print “Test1\nTest3” in the command line and “Test2” in the text area.
[/quote]
That looks like its taking the output of the java program, i just quickly skimmed it, but i mean run a totally different batch file, and get the text off of it to be on my jtextarea.[/quote]

You would somehow have to do some haxxor work in the cmd to do that. Otherwise you could waste your time and make a color script identify letters in the command window and build output Strings…

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:16, topic:176880”][code]
public class Test {
public static void main(String[] args) {
System.out.println(“Test 1”);
javax.swing.JFrame frame = new javax.swing.JFrame(“Test Frame”);
frame.setSize(300, 300);
javax.swing.JTextArea area = new javax.swing.JTextArea();
java.io.PrintStream stream = System.out;
System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(area, stream));
frame.add(new javax.swing.JScrollPane(area));
frame.setVisible(true);
System.out.println(“Test 2”);
System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(null, stream));
System.out.println(“Test 3”);
}
}

private class TestPrintStream extends java.io.PrintStream {
javax.swing.TextArea area;

public TestPrintStream(javax.swing.TextArea area, java.io.PrintStream stream) {
	super(stream);
	this.area = area;
}

public void println(String str) {
	if (area != null)
		area.setText(area.getText() + str + "\n");
	else
		super.println(str);
}

}
[/code]

I made this just now so I do not know if it would compile. However, if it would, it would print “Test1\nTest3” in the command line and “Test2” in the text area.[/quote]
That looks like its taking the output of the java program, i just quickly skimmed it, but i mean run a totally different batch file, and get the text off of it to be on my jtextarea.

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

public class Test {
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		System.out.println("Test 1");
		javax.swing.JFrame frame = new javax.swing.JFrame("Test Frame");
		frame.setSize(300, 300);
		javax.swing.JTextArea area = new javax.swing.JTextArea();
		java.io.PrintStream stream = System.out;
		System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(area, stream));
		frame.add(new javax.swing.JScrollPane(area));
		frame.setVisible(true);
		System.out.println("Test 2");
		System.setOut(new TestPrintStream(null, stream));
		System.out.println("Test 3");
	}
}

private class TestPrintStream extends java.io.PrintStream {
	javax.swing.TextArea area;

	public TestPrintStream(javax.swing.TextArea area, java.io.PrintStream stream) {
		super(stream);
		this.area = area;
	}

	public void println(String str) {
		if (area != null)
			area.setText(area.getText() + str + "\n");
		else
			super.println(str);
	}
}

I made this just now so I do not know if it would compile. However, if it would, it would print “Test1\nTest3” in the command line and “Test2” in the text area.

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

speedster239:

Override the System.out.println() methods to print into your own JTextArea.

I corrected you. And the only way you can overwrite those methods is by using the System.setOut() because System and all of its fields are static and are defined before your application even starts.

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?

item.description:

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You beat me to it

Yea, just override the PrintStream the System class uses. You can read from the PrintStream and append it in some sort of TextArea or TextPane like Mopar does.

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Or do you mean you’d like to run a batch file and print all of it’s output into the little black area down the bottem of the UI?

Exactly.

Read full topic

item.title: CMD Promp in application?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Wait, down the bottem there’s a little “config” window I guess, so just add a black text area and append to it when you need to?

Or do you mean you’d like to run a batch file and print all of it’s output into the little black area down the bottem of the UI?
If so just do something like;

Process p = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("somebatch.bat"); BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(p.getInputStream())); String input; while((input = in.readLine()) != null) { someTextArea.append(input); }

That is pretty much made of phaile, but I couldn’t think of any other way, if you’re trying to compile, like run a batch file which is calling javac, you may need to read the error stream to, just in case any errors are thrown, same with exceptions.

Read full topic
